channel.title: Compression on Infinity Architect
channel.description: Recent content in Compression on Infinity Architect

item.title: Zlib and DEFLATE: A Top-Down Introduction
item.description: Zlib was authored by Jean-loup Gailly (compression) and Mark Adler (decompression). Jean-loup is also the primary author of the compression routines of gzip and Info-ZIP’s Zip. Mark is also the author of the decompression routines of gzip and Info-ZIP’s UnZip. 1# ls -l /usr/lib/libz.* 2-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 130742 Oct 25 08:55 /usr/lib/libz.a 3lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 11 Oct 25 08:55 /usr/lib/libz.so -> libz.so.1.3 4lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 11 Oct 25 08:55 /usr/lib/libz.

item.title: LZ77
item.description: I recently went through the original paper of LZ77 so it might be a good chance to put down some synopsis and ideas. LZ77 was proposed in an age when compression algorithms are studied in the name of encoding and decoding processes. Terminologies were aligned with the classic coding theory. See [] The vanilla Ziv Lempel 1977 The following discussion uses notations from the lz77 paper in best effort. Some definitions are re-phrased.

item.title: The Unix compress(1) utility
item.description: The compress command appeared in 4.3BSD. It is popular in the 90s. A compressed file created by the compress command usually have a .Z extension. tar is usually in combined, creating an .tar.Z or .TAZ archive of a directory. Deflate compression support was added in OpenBSD 2.1. https://man.openbsd.org/compress
